title: UK economy on 'firm footing' as growth steps up a gear
text:

Fri, Jul 31, 2015, 06:42 BST - UK Markets open in 1 hr 18 mins UK economy on 'firm footing' as growth steps up a gear By Szu Ping Chan | Telegraph – 42 minutes ago GFK.SW 0.00 
Confederation of British Industry says low oil prices and inflation will continue to boost British households, supporting growth for the rest of this year 
UK growth "firmed up" in the three months to July, in a sign that the economy is on course for robust expansion for the rest of the year. 
The Confederation of British Industry's (CBI) latest growth indicator showed the economy has strengthened over the past three months, with Britain's services sector, which accounts for around three quarters of UK gross domestic product (GDP), driving output. 
The CBI said professional services companies expanded at a strong pace, while manufacturers and retailers reported "moderate" growth. 
“A healthy pace of growth puts the economy on a firm footing going into the third quarter and it looks set to stay that way through the rest of this year, as low oil prices and inflation help support spending," said Anna Leach, head of economic analysis at the CBI. 
The economy expanded by 0.7pc in the three months to the end of June , following growth of 0.4pc in the first three months of this year. 
The CBI's growth indicator suggested growth was firming up (Source: CBI) 
However, Ms Leach said the strong pound was likely to provide a "headache" for Britain's exporters trying to sell inside the eurozone. 
The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR), the governments' fiscal watchdog, expects net trade to act as a drag on growth for the next five years. 
Britain's biggest business lobby group said continued uncertainty in Greece and the recent turmoil in China would also act as headwinds. 
The CBI's survey of 736 companies showed a greater number of businesses reported growth in output volumes in the three months to July than a decline, resulting in a positive balance of 20pc. This was stronger than June's reading of 14pc. 
Optimism about future growth also remained high, with a positive balance of 27pc of companies expecting stronger growth over the next three months . 
It came as GfK’s UK consumer confidence index fell in July, with three of the five measures used to calculate the index registering decreases. 
Joe Staton, head of market dynamics at GfK (Swiss: GFK.SW - news ) , said: “Concerns about the general economic situation in the UK for the next 12 months appear to be weighing heavily on consumers’ minds at present. 
"However, on a more personal level, consumers remain resolutely upbeat about their own financial situation for the coming 12 months."
